That's perfect. Now how do I post this on Facebook so people will actually see it?

Great! Now that you've got your message ready, here are some tips to help you post it on Facebook so more people actually see it:

---

### ✅ **1. Post on the Right Page or Group**
- If your town or community has a **Facebook group** or **event page**, post the potluck there — that’s where people are more likely to see it.
- If it's a private group, make sure the post is **public** or set to "Visible to Group Members."

---

### ✅ **2. Create a Facebook Event (Best Option)**
Creating an **event** gives your potluck more visibility and makes it easier for people to RSVP and share.

**How to create a Facebook event:**
1. Go to [facebook.com/events/create](https://www.facebook.com/events/create)
2. Fill in the details:
   - **Event Name**: June Potluck
   - **Date & Time**: Saturday, June 15 at 5:00 PM
   - **Location**: [Your town hall address]
   - **Description**: Paste your message (you can add a friendly note like “Bring a dish and a friend!”)
   - **Privacy**: Public (to maximize reach) or Group (if posting in a community group)
3. Click **Create**.
4. After creating, you can **tag the town hall** or **community page** to boost visibility.

---

### ✅ **3. Post on Your Personal Page (If You’re the Host)**
If you're hosting, post the message on **your own Facebook page** and tag the town hall or community group. This helps friends and family see it in their feeds.

Example post:
> 📅 **You’re invited!**  
> Join us for our June potluck on **Saturday, June 15 at 5:00 PM** at the **town hall**.  
> Bring a dish and a friend!  
> Looking forward to seeing you there.  
> 📍 [Tag the town hall here]

---

### ✅ **4. Use a Clear Photo or Cover Image (Optional)**
If you want it to stand out more, add a simple image like:
- A photo of the town hall
- A generic potluck image (you can find free ones on Unsplash or Pexels)
- A hand-drawn sign or chalkboard with the date and time

---

### ✅ **5. Remind People a Few Days Before**
Post a **reminder** a few days before the event:
> Quick reminder: Our June potluck is this **Saturday, June 15 at 5:00 PM at the town hall**!  
> Don’t forget to bring a dish and a friend. See you there!

---

### Bonus Tip:
Encourage people to **RSVP in the comments** or **share the event** so more folks see it.

---

I don't want to create a whole event. I just want to post it on the town's Facebook page like a regular post. How do I do that without it getting buried?

Got it — if you want to **post it as a regular post** on the **town’s Facebook page**, but still **increase the chances people see it**, here’s how to do it effectively and **avoid it getting buried**:

---

### 🧠 **Step-by-Step: Posting on the Town’s Facebook Page**

1. **Log in to the town’s Facebook page** (or get the person who manages it to post it).
2. **Write a clear, friendly post** using your message (like the one you already have):
   ```
   📅 You’re invited!  
   Join us for our June potluck on **Saturday, June 15 at 5:00 PM** at the **town hall**.  
   Bring a dish and a friend!  

   Looking forward to seeing you there.
   ```

3. **Add a photo or image** (optional but helpful for visibility):
   - A photo of the town hall
   - A simple graphic with the date and time
   - A friendly photo of a potluck or picnic

4. **Tag relevant pages or groups**:
   - Tag the **town hall** page
   - If there’s a **community Facebook group**, mention it in the post or suggest people share it there
   - You can even **tag the event** if you later create one

5. **Post during a good time**:
   - Try to post **between 10 AM and 2 PM on a weekday** — that’s when most people are active on Facebook
   - Avoid posting late at night or early in the morning

---

### 🚀 **How to Make It More Likely to Be Seen (Without Boosting)**

- **Add a call to action**:  
  > “Please share this with anyone who might be interested!”

- **Use a **few** emojis** to make it eye-catching, but not too many. Your original message is perfect.

- **Mention key details first**:  
  Start with the **date, time, and location** so people can quickly scan and see if they’re interested.

- **Pin the post** (if you have admin access):
  - If the town page has many posts, **pin this one to the top** so it stays visible

---

### 📌 Example Post (Clean & Clear)

```
📅 You’re invited!  
Join us for our June potluck on **Saturday, June 15 at 5:00 PM** at the **town hall**.  
Bring a dish and a friend!  

Looking forward to seeing you there.  
```

---

### 🛑 Avoid These Common Pitfalls:
- Don’t post it and then forget — **check in a few days before** to make sure people remember
- Don’t post it at the last minute — give people **at least a week’s notice**
- Don’t post it in a group with no context — if it’s a group, **write a short message** like:  
  _“Just a reminder that the June potluck is Saturday, June 15 at 5 PM at the town hall. Bring a dish and a friend!”_

---

2. **Tag the town hall** in the post:

   - A simple image with the event details

- **Tag the town hall in the caption**, not just in the photo — this helps with visibility.

- **Mention the event in your story** (if you use Facebook Stories) for extra exposure.

@Town Hall Name

I don't use Facebook much. When I type @ and the town hall name, nothing shows up. What am I doing wrong?

No worries — this is super common, especially if you don’t use Facebook often. Let’s walk through **how to tag the town hall correctly**, step by step. It’s easier than it looks!

---

### 🛠️ **How to Tag the Town Hall in Your Facebook Post**

1. **Start a new post** on your Facebook timeline.
2. **Type your message** like this:

   ```
   📅 You’re invited!  
   Join us for our June potluck on **Saturday, June 15 at 5:00 PM** at the **town hall**.  
   Bring a dish and a friend!  

   Looking forward to seeing you there.  
   ```

3. **Now, type an `@` symbol** right where you want to tag the town hall — like at the end of your message or after the location.

4. **Start typing the name of the town hall or town page** — for example:
   - `@Town Hall`
   - `@My Town Name`
   - `@MyTown Community Page`

5. **Facebook will pop up a list of suggestions** — it might look like this:
   - `@Town Hall (Page)`
   - `@MyTown Community (Page)`
   - `@MyTown Official (Page)`

6. **Click on the correct one** from the list. Facebook will now **tag the page** and notify them (and their followers) that you mentioned them.

---

### 🚫 Why It Might Not Be Showing Up

If **nothing shows up** when you type `@`, it could be one of these reasons:

- The **town hall doesn’t have a Facebook page** (yet).
- You’re **spelling the name incorrectly**.
- You’re typing `@` in the wrong place (e.g., in the photo caption instead of the text).

---

### ✅ **Alternative: Just Mention the Town Hall in the Caption**

If the town hall **doesn’t have a page**, or you can’t find it, just **type out the name clearly** and **ask people to share**:

```
📅 You’re invited!  
Join us for our June potluck on **Saturday, June 15 at 5:00 PM** at the **town hall**.  
Bring a dish and a friend!  

Looking forward to seeing you there.  
#PleaseShare
```

Then, **after posting**, you can **click the “Tag Friends” button** and tag people who might help spread the word.

---

### 📸 Tip: Add a Photo

If you can take a **quick photo of the event details** or the town hall, add it to the post. People are more likely to stop and read it.

---

### 🧪 Example of a Full Post

```
📅 You’re invited!  
Join us for our June potluck on **Saturday, June 15 at 5:00 PM** at the **town hall**.  
Bring a dish and a friend!  

Looking forward to seeing you there.  
@MyTown Hall
```

---
